questions.ocrQuestion:
A bomb explodes on the moon. You will hear its sound on earth after:
a. \( 10 \mathrm{~min} \)
b. 2 hour \( 18 \mathrm{~min} \)
c. \( 37 \mathrm{~min} \)
d. never
questions.onlyq_text: A bomb explodes on the moon. You will hear its sound on earth after:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
If \( c_{0} \) and \( c \) denote the sound velocity and root mean square velocity of molecules in a gas, then:
a. \( c_{0}>c \)
b. \( c_{0}=c \)
c. \( c_{0}=c(\gamma / 3)^{1 / 2} \)
d. \( c_{0} \) and \( c \) are not related
questions.onlyq_text: If \( c_{0} \) and \( c \) denote the sound velocity and root mean square velocity of molecules in a gas, then:

options.option: d. \( c_{0} \) and \( c \) are not related

questions.sol_html: (c) \( C_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma R T}{m}} \) and \( C=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}} \)\[\frac{C_{0}}{C}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{3}} \text { or } C_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{3}} C\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A transverse wave is described by the equation \( y=y_{0} \sin 2 \pi\left(f t-\frac{x}{\lambda}\right) \). The maximum particle velocity is equal to four times the wave velocity if:
a. \( \lambda=\frac{\pi y_{0}}{4} \)
b. \( \lambda=\frac{\pi y_{0}}{2} \)
c. \( \lambda=\pi y_{0} \)
d. \( \lambda=2 \pi y_{0} \)
questions.onlyq_text: A transverse wave is described by the equation \( y=y_{0} \sin 2 \pi\left(f t-\frac{x}{\lambda}\right) \). The maximum particle velocity is equal to four times the wave velocity if:
questions.sol_html: (b) \( y=y_{0} \sin 2 \pi\left(f t-\frac{x}{\lambda}\right) \)Wave velocity \( v=f_{A} \)Particle velocity \( u=\frac{d y}{d t}=y_{0} \cdot 2 \pi f \cos 2 \pi\left(f t-\frac{\pi}{\lambda}\right) \)\[\begin{array}{l}u_{\max }=y_{0} \cdot 2 \pi f \\\text { Given } u_{\max }=4 v \\y_{0} 2 \pi f=4 f_{\lambda} \Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{\pi y_{0}}{2}\end{array}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The amplitude of a wave disturbance propagating along positive \( X \)-axis given by \( y=\frac{1}{1+x^{2}} \) at \( t=0 \) and \( y=\frac{1}{1+(x-2)^{2}} \) at \( t=4 \mathrm{sec} \) where \( x \) and \( y \) are in meter. The shape of wave disturbance does not change with time. The velocity of the wave is:
a. \( 0.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
b. \( 1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
c. \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
d. \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
questions.onlyq_text: The amplitude of a wave disturbance propagating along positive \( X \)-axis given by \( y=\frac{1}{1+x^{2}} \) at \( t=0 \) and \( y=\frac{1}{1+(x-2)^{2}} \) at \( t=4 \mathrm{sec} \) where \( x \) and \( y \) are in meter. The shape of wave disturbance does not change with time. The velocity of the wave is:
questions.sol_html: \( \begin{array}{l}\text { (a) } y=\frac{1}{1+x^{2}} \text { at } t=0 \\ \text { and } y=\frac{1}{1+(x-2)^{2}} \text { at } t=4 \mathrm{~s} \\ v=\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}=\frac{x-(x-2)}{4-0}=\frac{2}{4}=0.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\end{array} \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A string stretched at both ends is under a tension of 100 \( N \). If mass of string is \( 4 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{cm} \), the velocity of transverse waves in string is:
a. \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
b. \( 50 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
c. \( 500 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
d. \( 5000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
questions.onlyq_text: A string stretched at both ends is under a tension of 100 \( N \). If mass of string is \( 4 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{cm} \), the velocity of transverse waves in string is:

questions.ocrQuestion:
There is \( 1 \mathrm{~mm} \) vacuum between two walls. The speed of sound in air is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) and speed of light in vacuum is \( 3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \). The time taken by sound to traverse the distance of \( 1 \mathrm{~mm} \) form one wall to another through vacuum is:
a. \( 0.3 \mathrm{~s} \)
b. \( 1 \mathrm{~min} \)
c. \( 1 \mu \mathrm{s} \)
d. \( \infty \)
questions.onlyq_text: There is \( 1 \mathrm{~mm} \) vacuum between two walls. The speed of sound in air is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) and speed of light in vacuum is \( 3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \). The time taken by sound to traverse the distance of \( 1 \mathrm{~mm} \) form one wall to another through vacuum is:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
In a sinusoidal wave, the time required for a particular point to move form maximum displacement zero displacement is \( 0.170 \mathrm{sec} \). The frequency of the wave is:
a. \( 1.47 \mathrm{~Hz} \)
b. \( 0.36 \mathrm{~Hz} \)
c. \( 0.73 \mathrm{~Hz} \)
d. \( 2.94 \mathrm{~Hz} \)
questions.onlyq_text: In a sinusoidal wave, the time required for a particular point to move form maximum displacement zero displacement is \( 0.170 \mathrm{sec} \). The frequency of the wave is:

questions.ocrQuestion:
A man standing in front of a high wall hears his echo after \( 2 \mathrm{sec} \). If speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), his distance from the wall is:
a. \( 165 \mathrm{~m} \)
b. \( 330 \mathrm{~m} \)
c. \( 495 \mathrm{~m} \)
d. \( 660 \mathrm{~m} \)
questions.onlyq_text: A man standing in front of a high wall hears his echo after \( 2 \mathrm{sec} \). If speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), his distance from the wall is:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
An echo repeats two syllables. If the speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), then the minimum distance of reflecting surface is:
a. \( 16.5 \mathrm{~m} \)
b. \( 33.0 \mathrm{~m} \)
c. \( 66.0 \mathrm{~m} \)
d. \( 330 \mathrm{~m} \)
questions.onlyq_text: An echo repeats two syllables. If the speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), then the minimum distance of reflecting surface is:
questions.sol_html: (c) \( S=\frac{v t}{2} \)For syllabic sound \( t=\frac{1}{5} \) second per syllable for two syllables \( t=2 \times \frac{1}{5} \) second\[S=\frac{330 \times(2 / 5)}{2}=66 \mathrm{~m}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
It is noticed that if the rate of clapping 100 per minute, the original sound cannot be distinguished from the sound reflected from a wall. If the speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), the distance of wall form the man is:
a. \( 33 \mathrm{~m} \)
b. \( 99 \mathrm{~m} \)
c. \( 132 \mathrm{~m} \)
d. \( 198 \mathrm{~m} \)
questions.onlyq_text: It is noticed that if the rate of clapping 100 per minute, the original sound cannot be distinguished from the sound reflected from a wall. If the speed of sound is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), the distance of wall form the man is:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A man stands in a narrow, steep-sided valley. When he shouts he hears two echoes, one after \( 1 \mathrm{sec} \) and the other after \( 2 \mathrm{sec} \). If the velocity of sound in air is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), the width of the valley is:
a. \( 330 \mathrm{~m} \)
b. \( 495 \mathrm{~m} \)
c. \( 660 \mathrm{~m} \)
d. \( 990 \mathrm{~m} \)
questions.onlyq_text: A man stands in a narrow, steep-sided valley. When he shouts he hears two echoes, one after \( 1 \mathrm{sec} \) and the other after \( 2 \mathrm{sec} \). If the velocity of sound in air is \( 330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), the width of the valley is:
questions.sol_html: (b) Let \( S_{1} \) and \( S_{2} \) be the distance of man form either side of valley, then \( 2 S_{1}=v t_{1} \) and \( 2 S_{2}=v t_{2} \)\[\begin{array}{l}2\left(S_{1}+S_{2}\right)=v\left(t_{1}+t_{2}\right) \\S_{1}+S_{2}=\frac{v\left(t_{1}+t_{2}\right)}{2} \\d=S_{1}+S_{2}=\frac{330(1+2)}{2}=495 \mathrm{~m}\end{array}\]
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The ratio of intensities of two interfering waves is \( 4: 1 \), then the ratio of maximum to minimum intensity is:
a. \( 1: 4 \)
b. \( 9: 1 \)
c. \( 4: 1 \)
d. \( 3: 1 \)
questions.onlyq_text: The ratio of intensities of two interfering waves is \( 4: 1 \), then the ratio of maximum to minimum intensity is:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Two plane waves of same frequencies having intensities I and 4I, are travelling in the same direction. The resultant intensity at a maxima at which waves meet is:
a. I
b. 3I
c. \( 5 \mathrm{I} \)
d. 9I
questions.onlyq_text: Two plane waves of same frequencies having intensities I and 4I, are travelling in the same direction. The resultant intensity at a maxima at which waves meet is:
questions.sol_html: \( \begin{array}{l}\text { (d) } I_{\max }=a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+2 a_{1} a_{2} \\ =I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}}=I+4 I+2 \times \sqrt{I \times 4 I}=9 I\end{array} \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

c. \( 90^{\circ} \)
d. \( 120^{\circ} \)

questions.ocrQuestion:
Out of the following four sources \( S_{1}, S_{2}, S_{3} \) and \( S_{4} \) only two are coherent, which can produce interference:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
S_{1}, y=A \sin 100 \pi t \\
S_{2}, y=A \sin 101 \pi t \\
S_{3}, y=A \cos 100 \pi t \\
S_{4}, y=A \cos 102 \pi t
\end{array}
\]

The coherent sources are
a. \( S_{1} \) and \( S_{2} \)
b. \( S_{1} \) and \( S_{3} \)
c. \( S_{2} \) and \( S_{3} \)
d. \( S_{3} \) and \( S_{4} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Out of the following four sources \( S_{1}, S_{2}, S_{3} \) and \( S_{4} \) only two are coherent, which can produce interference:\[\begin{array}{l}S_{1}, y=A \sin 100 \pi t \\S_{2}, y=A \sin 101 \pi t \\S_{3}, y=A \cos 100 \pi t \\S_{4}, y=A \cos 102 \pi t\end{array}\]The coherent sources are
questions.sol_html: (b) Interfering waves must have same frequency.
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Out of given four waves a., b., c. and d.
\[
\begin{array}{l}
y=20 \sin 100 \pi t \\
y=20 \sin 101 \pi t \\
y=20 \cos (100 \pi t) \\
y=20 \cos (101 \pi t)
\end{array}
\]
emitted by four \( S_{1}, S_{2}, S_{3} \) and \( S_{4} \) respectively.
Interference phenomenon will be observed in space when:
a. source \( S_{1} \) emits wave a. and \( S_{4} \) emits wave d.
b. source \( S_{2} \) emits wave b. and \( S_{4} \) emits wave d.
c. source \( S_{1} \) emits wave a. and \( S_{3} \) emits wave c.
d. Interference phenomenon cannot be observed by the combination of any of the above waves
questions.onlyq_text: Out of given four waves a., b., c. and d.\[\begin{array}{l}y=20 \sin 100 \pi t \\y=20 \sin 101 \pi t \\y=20 \cos (100 \pi t) \\y=20 \cos (101 \pi t)\end{array}\]emitted by four \( S_{1}, S_{2}, S_{3} \) and \( S_{4} \) respectively.Interference phenomenon will be observed in space when:

options.option: a. source \( S_{1} \) emits wave a. and \( S_{4} \) emits wave d.
b. source \( S_{2} \) emits wave b. and \( S_{4} \) emits wave d.
c. source \( S_{1} \) emits wave a. and \( S_{3} \) emits wave c.
d. Interference phenomenon cannot be observed by the combination of any of the above waves

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Two coherent sound waves arrive at a point traversing different paths of lengths \( L_{1} \) and \( L_{2} \). To hear maximum sound at that point, the condition is:
a. \( L_{1}-L_{2}=n \lambda \)
b. \( L_{1}-L_{2}=(2 n-1)(\lambda / 2) \)
c. \( L_{1}-L_{2}=[n+(1 / 4)] \lambda \)
d. \( L_{1}-L_{2}=[n+(1 / 2)](\lambda / 2) \)
questions.onlyq_text: Two coherent sound waves arrive at a point traversing different paths of lengths \( L_{1} \) and \( L_{2} \). To hear maximum sound at that point, the condition is:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
Consider 10 identical sources of sound all giving the same frequency but having random phase angles. If the average intensity of each source is \( I_{0} \), the average of resultant intensity \( I \) due to all these 10 sources will be:
a. \( I=100 I_{0} \)
b. \( I=10 I_{0} \)
c. \( I=I_{0} \)
d. \( I=\sqrt{10} I_{0} \)
questions.onlyq_text: Consider 10 identical sources of sound all giving the same frequency but having random phase angles. If the average intensity of each source is \( I_{0} \), the average of resultant intensity \( I \) due to all these 10 sources will be:
questions.sol_html: (b) For incoherent sources \( I \sum I_{0}=10 I_{0} \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
The plane wave represent by an equation of the form \( y=f(x-v t) \) implies the propagation along the positive \( x \) axis without change of shape with constant velocity:
a. \( \frac{d v}{d t}=-v\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right) \)
b. \( \frac{d v}{d t}=-v\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right) \)
c. \( \frac{d^{2} v}{d t^{2}}=-v^{2}\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right) \)
d. \( \frac{d^{2} v}{d t^{2}}=v\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right) \)
questions.onlyq_text: The plane wave represent by an equation of the form \( y=f(x-v t) \) implies the propagation along the positive \( x \) axis without change of shape with constant velocity:
questions.sol_html: Consider for example the equation of the form:\[\begin{array}{l}y=a \sin (\omega t-k x) \\\frac{d y}{d t}=a \omega \cos (\omega t-k x) \\\frac{d y}{d x}=-a k \cos (\omega t-k x)\end{array}\]Hence, \( \frac{d y}{d t}=-\left(\frac{\omega}{k}\right) \frac{d y}{d x}=-v\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right) \)i.e., choice (a) is correct.Now,\( \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}=a \omega^{2} \sin (\omega t-k x)=-\omega^{2} y \)\[\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=+k^{2} a \sin (\omega t-k x)=k^{2} y\]\( \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}=-\left(\frac{\omega^{2}}{k^{2}}\right) \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=-v^{2}\left(\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}\right) \) i.e., choice (c) is correct.
questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A wave is represented by the equation. \( y=A \sin \left(10 \pi x+15 \pi t+\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \) where \( x \) is in meter and \( t \) is the second. The expression represents:
a. A wave traveling in the positive \( x \)-direction with a velocity \( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
b. A wave traveling in the negative \( x \)-direction with a velocity \( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
c. A wave traveling in the negative \( x \)-direction have a wavelength \( 0.2 \mathrm{~m} \)
d. A wave traveling in the positive \( x \)-direction have a wavelength \( 0.2 \mathrm{~m} \)
questions.onlyq_text: A wave is represented by the equation. \( y=A \sin \left(10 \pi x+15 \pi t+\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \) where \( x \) is in meter and \( t \) is the second. The expression represents:

options.option: a. A wave traveling in the positive \( x \)-direction with a velocity \( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
b. A wave traveling in the negative \( x \)-direction with a velocity \( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
c. A wave traveling in the negative \( x \)-direction have a wavelength \( 0.2 \mathrm{~m} \)
d. A wave traveling in the positive \( x \)-direction have a wavelength \( 0.2 \mathrm{~m} \)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.ocrQuestion:
A transvers sinusoidal wave of amplitude a, wavelength \( \lambda \) and frequency \( f \) is traveling on a stretched string. The maximum speed at any point on the string is \( (v / 10) \) where \( \mathrm{v} \) is speed of propagation of the wave. If \( a=10^{-3} \) \( \mathrm{m} \) and \( v=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), then \( \lambda \) and \( f \) are given by
a. \( \lambda=2 \pi \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m} \)
b. \( \lambda=10^{-3} \mathrm{~m} \)
c. \( \lambda=10^{3} /(2 \pi) \mathrm{Hz} \)
d. \( f=10^{4} \mathrm{~Hz} \)
questions.onlyq_text: A transvers sinusoidal wave of amplitude a, wavelength \( \lambda \) and frequency \( f \) is traveling on a stretched string. The maximum speed at any point on the string is \( (v / 10) \) where \( \mathrm{v} \) is speed of propagation of the wave. If \( a=10^{-3} \) \( \mathrm{m} \) and \( v=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), then \( \lambda \) and \( f \) are given by
questions.sol_html: (a,c) \( v_{\max }=a \omega=a(2 \pi f) \)Given that \( a(2 \pi f)=\frac{v}{10}=\frac{10}{10}=1 \) \( f=\frac{1}{2 \pi f}=\frac{10^{3}}{2 \pi} \) Hz As \( v=f \lambda \) \( \lambda=\frac{v}{f}=\frac{10}{10^{3} / 2 \pi}=2 \pi \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m} \)
questions.subject: PHYSICS
